transcript: um typical day i i get up fairly early in the morning about 6x o'clock i either go into the office to to work there or i work from home by dialing in on my on my computer um i work on designing a database or solving problems around the design of a database and i work right through until five or six o'clock depending on the requirements of the project um i take a break for lunch um and that's uh pretty much my work day uh come home or i am at home and have supper with my wife and spend the evening doing different things sometimes just watching television sometimes going out for a walk sometimes visiting with friends um sometimes i'm going out to to large meeting

um a specific event or i did a cano trip in 1998 21 days paddling on the mckensay river in the northwest territories to do a historical reenactment of the trip to the clondike that was used by the prospecters trying to get there and that was a once in a lifetime kind of experience i uh was with initially five other people two of them dropped out part way through the trip because they they didn't consider it safe but it was uh it was a fascinating trip to see that that part of the world and we paddled in one case past two days of forest fires on one bank of the river and the smoke we had to put claws over our mouths to to to be able to breathe properly because the smoke was quite heavy uh the the paddling itself was not particularly onous because the current is very strong in the mackay river but we did paddle a lot we paddled nine or 10 hours a day uh to to keep going we we averaged about 72 kilometers a day on on the padding um covered almost 1400 kilometers on the whole trip uh and surprisingly enough a low we were on a river drinking water was one of our biggest problems because mckensay river is a very silty river you can't see a half inch into the water so we had to find side streams that were clear in order to get fresh water to be able to drink

when i was three years old i have a very vivid memory of being left with my sister and having our a young woman who was taking care of us at home while my mother worked at the office with my dad at his store and it was the summer of 1946 and uh my sister i was i were playing in the this young gall wanted me to go have a nap in the afternoon in the summer day and i was protesting and i was so upset i went into the bedroom waited a few minutes and snuck out of the house and then walked on my own dance through the downtown to my dance stuff

and so i really didn't fit in um really it was at the end of the first year when i made my first real friend up until then i was friendly with people but i didn't understand the limits of that friendliness and it was very limited because we were told to get into study groups and i never spoke in class because i could never understand what they wanted like they asked questions for which the answer seemed obvious why would anybody say the obvious so people said the obvious and they were rewarded so those were the people sought after to be in the study groups not me so i did almost everything alone for the entire year and when i asked to borrow one of my friends notes she said she had to get permission from her group because they couldn't share notes outside the group so i said thanks but no thanks don't bother and somewhere along the line i found a group that really didn't give a shit just anybody you wanted to could be part of it that was me so i was part of that group for seven classes at the end of the year in the subway station i met someone who i'm still friends with i just adore um but we had been divided into two groups of 50 or 75 people and she was in the other group so i never saw her and in second year things improved a bit because then i think i made a second friend and that was good like once i had a couple of friends to talk to and especially one or two in the year ahead so that was a bit better as an example of the incredible snobbiness of the school and the students who all thought they were special we had one class in session second year with a teacher who was really a decent person and he said please when you write your exams don't think that your mark is a reflection of your quality as a human being and i thought wow it is so amazing to hear something like that

start off with uh reading the newspaper at about 7:30 8 o'clock in in the morning and uh i have different activities i'm pretty involved with curling and i curl two at least two times a week in the mornings and with a seniors group and uh sometimes uh not so much anymore but it was one time competitive curling uh in a competitive league and uh that's one of the things that occupies a lot time in the winter time i'm also on the board of our condominium corporation and i'm treasurer of of that so responsible for no considerable amount of money we have probably a million and a half to million and three quarters dollars in our reserve fund that needs to be managed and uh board meetings are about once a month but there's also activities that are weekly and uh summertime uh we do a little bit of traveling a little winter a little bit of traveling in the winter time too and uh a little bit of golf in the summertime and uh that takes up most of my day watching sports and television in the particularly hockey baseball

okay i was running to my class at university to my finance class from my sociology class next thing i knew i woke up looked at my wrist watch it was still on shockpoof by the way said 8:20 and the clock on the wall said 5:9 so i assumed something had happened yes something had happened i i had two broken legs and i was in the hospital emergency uh i remained there for three and a half months and was able to get out of bed and walk and walking down the hall i lost my balance on my crutches and i put my bad leg down on the floor and broke it again uh and then they took me back to bed with the wheelchair and i got into bed and the nurse came in and i said am i going to the operating room and she said yes and i went to the operator room was put in a body cast from under my underarms to the tip of my left toe and i had to remain in that for another eight weeks and and i finally got out of bed and learned to walk again of course cuz you can't walk when you're in bed for that long i came out of the hospital my accident was october 12th came out of the hospital march 29th and that night i went to university to write a test so um and then i have to really learn to walk cuz i was on croches at the time and i learned to walk and now i walk all over the city of toronto and in miami beach all over miami beach and while in the hospital they would bring ambulatory patients to my room because they were depressed disregarding that except for going for x-rays i was in this room room at that point for four months but i took the approach that there's nothing when you there's nothing you can do about something don't waste your energy move on and make the best of the situation so the highlight of my day was watching jepardy

you're my cousin anne um she's 71 now and she had a stroke when she was 66 and so she's left-handed and so she lost the use of her right side her hand is all bangled in her foot also and her communication skills are very limited she's it's a phasia is what i think she has and uh she's gotten progressively better over the years initially she could just repeat the same phrase over and over again she used to always say zoom zoom zoom zoom and i always because she was in a car she was sitting in a her parked car when she had the stroke and um she doesn't say that anymore but a lot of the people where she lives that's her nickname is zoom zoom because she used to say that a lot but she's very challenging to communicate with um and i'll go see her and spend an hour or so and we have lunch and um things and we try to communicate as well best as we can with asking her simple questions and she communicates in a sort of a roundabout way she has three children and when she wants to talk about them she can't always get their name but she'll say one two or three and that's how we know cuz she somehow she brings a lot of numbers and when she tries to tell you she's in pain she'll say her good hand and she'll say one two three four five off pain i don't know i don't know like that she's somehow it's amazing how she communicates i give her a lot of credit

yeah the toughest uh thing i had on communication really dealt with a foreign language i was blessed to be able to financially handle going to thailand last year to work with the jimmy carter international foundation and there were about 12 to 15 people from luxington that went and we ended up building 82 houses in a 2-week period we had over a thousand volunteers and even with some of the people from different countries you had some dialect type communication problems but in thailand we had interpreters on site that if we had to ask a technical question of someone uh we would have that ability we also had a lady from lexington a lady by the name of tau who is the cook in her parents owned a tai restaurant here in town the york cafe she was along and uh she helped us many times because uh on each house the home owners had to be there during the time that we were there and they mixed to concrete and carry bricks just like all of us did

but there was one thailand individual there who had worked on he was like a local volunteer for uh from thailand and at times i had a hard time communicating with him because uh he would say things and smile and you would think that well maybe that smile was in agreement but other times it wasn't and also having been experienced in building houses in thailand he had some initiative uh with all of us americans working on his house here was 26-28 americans on the house all of us uh we automatically like if somebody needed a hammer you could call over and ask for a hammer or if somebody took an initiative to go do something on their own we sort of accepted it because we knew that they had the intelligence to do that uh working with someone of with a foreign tongue you you know that person is just as intelligent as we might be and even more so but that lack of ability uh really messed me up personally and i you know uh at the beginning i felt sort of and uh i had to you know snitch on myself that i felt poorly about that person because i misjudged them and and i love working with people i just uh love the customer service driven type scenario

and uh early on in the week i guess i also i may not have known of his experience and uh that also probably helped me to misjudge him by the time the first week had gone halfway through though i learned more and more about him because it puzzled me when i go through life and things puzzle me i try to find an answer

i'm a guy that will ask for directions if i can lost and uh i did the same thing with this individual actually asking about and this several people and it was so neat that by the end of a week i was good friends with this person even though i couldn't carry on a long conversation that language barrier due to my understanding of the person became better as a a community communication more so than anything else that happened understanding the actual person

something that rings in my memory was that many years ago i was employed one summer to make a a study of nevaho indian experiences in temporary seasonal off reservation employment so i was supposed to be collecting interviews with people who had those experiences and when i first arrived in the area that i had chosen i had a great deal of trouble getting anybody wanted to talk to me i learned later it was because some rumors i got around about what this information was going to be used for but there was a navajo ceremony going on uh at the time and i learned about this and i i realized from long experience on the reservation that if you're ever going to find a large population of people without very much to do it's it's at the at the sing as we call and so i went to the location of the sing and i uh set up shop under a pinon tree and i started trying to find people to talk to well before very long the lead medicine man singer as we call them was conducting the ceremony inside the the hat hogan learned about this and he came out and asked me what was going on and i explained why i was there and why this why this information was being collected and what i was to do and he was very favorable and so he asked me if i would come that night to the evening ceremony when everybody's standing in a big circle around to fire and make a speech and explain about what i was doing there and why and so i i came and i did indeed make i was the only white person there and i made this speech about and explaining the reason for my survey and what the information was to be used for and i was actually believe it or not giving a round of applause afterward and from that time on i never had any trouble getting interviews people were very anxious to come and talk to so next stand out in my mind is an experience that i like

okay to plant a flower in the garden the first thing that you need to do is dig a hole twice as big as the root or twice as big as the pot and then you need to mix some compost in with the soil that you just dug out put the plant back into the hole and fill around it with the mixture of the dirt and the compost and then you make a moound in the middle making sure that the root ball is just just covered and then you can make a little mote you make make a little moat around the uh dirt ball then you water it and as the dirt settles down you add more dirt if necessary and then saturate the soil to make sure that it has gotten all the way through to the water to the roots and that the soil is settled

make a peanut butter and jelly sandwich first you get out all the ingredients two slices of bread a jar of peanut butter a jar of jelly and a knife you open the two pieces of bread lay them out next to each other you open the jelly first and you scoop out however much jelly you want and spread it with the knife on on to one slice of bread and then you take your knife and you clean it on the other slice of bread before you dip it into the peanut butter jar you open the peanut butter jar dip your knife in get a nice big glob of peanut butter and then spread that onto the other slice of bread then you close your two pieces of bread together with with the peanut butter side facing the jelly side lay it down flat cut it in two or four pieces and then enjoy

on my last vacation we joined my best friend and her family in their rv going to the grand canyon there were seven of us four in my family and three in her family we loaded into the rv on a very stormy night here in phoenix as we head north towards the grand canyon the rain stopped stopped but that wasn't but we weren't in the clear a trucker passing us waved at us indicating that something was wrong and so we pulled over alongside the road and found that the vehicle we were towing behind the motor home had blown a tire and ripped up the whole front side of the truck we were towing while the children slept in the motor home the adults got out changed the tire and did the things that we needed to do and we proceeded on to flag staff we stayed in the walmart parking lot that night so that the very next morning we could wake up and get the tire fixed and proceed with our vacation the next morning after the tire was was fixed we drove up to the grand canyon and had a wonderful time even though we were a day late getting there because of our problems we had a wonderful time and we hiked into the grand canyon and out again we went to dinner and watched an imax movie and everybody had a wonderful time and it turned out to be a really good vacation despite the rough start

ah last weekend we went into the tonto national forest in pasen outside of pason to cut firewood i had gone to the ranger station in masa and bought a firewood cutting permit and so we packed up without any motor home just tents and sleeping bags and trailer uh uh trailer and chainsaw and axes and lots of food and cooking supplies for my mother-in-law and early saturday morning we drove up to payson we we followed along a dirt road that the ranger had recommended and we found a nice place to camp with lots of dead trees around us after we set up camp we unloaded our atv and we and we started dragging huge logs back up the hill to our camp we cut the logs we cut the the long tree stumps into logs and laid them next to the camper where we would load them the next day but mother-in-law was going to be sleeping in the camper or that not the camper but the trailer so we couldn't load till the next day my husband and i stayed in a tent on a air mattress and it was so nice it rained as we were going to sle asleep but we could still hear the crickets and uh the the popping of the fire just outside the tent and some and so that's that's how i went to sleep it was beautiful sometime during the night i woke up we woke up because it was a coyote howling close by so we got up and we opened up the tent the rain had passed the sky was clear the there's a million stars and we sat and listened to the coyote and um i was actually it was it was so dark out there besides the stars there was nobody else around us and i was able to get out of my sleeping bag and wander around in just my underwear and sneakers and it just felt so good cuz nobody could see me nobody cared and uh seems like i stayed up half the night looking at the stars and listening to the coyotes and and got up in the morning and and my grandma cooked pancakes and sausage over a propane grill and we loaded up the firewood and went on home it was one of the best weekends i'd had

i was in the military i had just come to phoenix from korea and i didn't know anybody yet and so i got a part-time job on the weekends working at a construction site as a security guard and i worked middle of the night shift all night shift and it was a 50 acre construction site out in the middle of nowhere before anything was developed and they had security at the site for insurance purposes however the security guards were not allowed to carry any weapons we weren't allowed to carry even a mag light because a maglite is considered a weapon there's actually classes to teach you how to use the maglite for self-defense or as a weapon so so on this 50 acre site there was one light pole and security guard was required to sit under that light pole unless they were making their rounds so all around you it's pitch black and you're just under this light pole and you can't see beyond the the darkness or beyond the light and so i would sit there at night and uh one night in the middle of the summer the construction crew came to work or they had been coming to work very very early in the morning this time it was around 3:00 in the morning and i didn't realize that they were going to be coming that early and i was sitting where i shouldn't have been sitting i was just outside the light so that i you can see cuz it's creepy

very creepy all night long and so by 3:00 in the morning i was already on edge and all of a sudden and i hadn't seen anybody approaching but all of a sudden a man jumped out from behind a close by porta potty he yelled and he had a rope in his hand and he was stretching the rope between his hands like this and he yelled and i screamed and he laughed and then he tied the rope around his waist where he was using it to hold his pants up and he continued to laugh and i cried because it had scared me so down
turns out he was just one of the construction workers that showed up early and maybe got dropped off along the road

okay the what i'm going to describe is an acoustic neuroma a craniatomy for the acoustic neuroma um i discovered this when i was talking on the telephone um working at the office had telephone up like this on this ear so i can write like this take notes it was a fairly long phone call i get stiff neck so i switched the telephone around to the other side and the volume sounded about twice as much as it was on the left side i switched the phone back to this side and it was much quieter so i figured there's something wrong with the ear my left ear is not hearing the way it should anyway went to an ent specialist and he diagnosed it as an acoustic neroma which is a little tumor that grows on the nerves that run through your skull we did some research found the surgeon who specialized in that type of surgery went out had the surgery performed for the surgery itself uh first thing i do is shave this side of your head um i had i got a haircut before i went out so it would be short so i wouldn't look like i had a real long hair on this side uh i remember the prep i remember the shaving for the uh for the surgery uh then you're under you're totally out of it i didn't wake up and have consciousness until what i think was the second day following the surgery uh they keep you out because they don't want you moving around uh the surgery involves cutting a hole in the head so they can get into where the nerves are uh get the tumor taken off of it afterwards it was a recovery uh that took um oh a week or 10 days before we recovered enough to be able to uh come back home i had a nice scar up this side of the head kind of shaped like a light bulb um and they put a stery tape on it uh to kind of hide it keep it steril the nice part about heading back was uh we'd go to the airport and i'd sit in the chair and i i'd sit so that that side of my head was toward the ticket counter and my wife would go over to the ticket counter and she'd say my husband's had some brain surgery and
